UX Case Study on the Spy Camera Detector Application "Relief's Map"

Social Trust and Learned Helplessness as Social Innovation Design Elements
full document in PDF

Abstract

What it means to design technologies for minority communities is a growing body of literature within HCI. This case study is concerned with the social context of Korea’s epidemic spy camera installation in public places for illicit purposes such as taking women’s photos or videos and oftentimes selling them on internet pornography websites. With the question of design and technology’s ability to solve social problems or to help minority communities, I analyzed how the digital product, spy camera detector application, offers vague means to understand women’s safety from spy cameras in Korea, and additionally how it wields the potential to abuse women’s fear and learned helplessness. Furthermore, I suggest the importance of application operators’ trust work with digital civics. Although the application is intended for for-profit purposes, trust is still a prerequisite for the product since it is based on the users’ participation to report the spy camera’s existence in public places within the app’s map. Additionally, I suggest that emerging technologies should not be designed for the status quo nor aggravate marginalized people’s existing fear. Through this case study, I emphasize the importance of acknowledging the complexity of the minority group’s social psychology centering around fear, learned helplessness, and indignation, to design for empowering minority groups and liberating them from angst and learned helplessness.

Keywords

#Trust #Community Engagement #Social Innovation Design #Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) #Learned Helplessness

Problem

Can Design Solve Social Problems?

Solution

"trust cannot be designed into a system," but "designers can aim to create optimal environmental conditions for the emergence of trust."
